item.title: The New Backbone Pro: Xbox Edition Brings Console-Style Controls To Your Phone
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Backbone has announced a new entry in its line of smartphone controllers, the Backbone Pro: Xbox Edition. This is priced at $180--$10 more than the regular Backbone Pro--and it is now available to purchase through retailers like Amazon, Best Buy, and Backbone's own online store. The controller also comes with one month of Xbox Game Pass Ultimate on the house, so you can check out The Outer Worlds 2 or any of the other big Game Pass releases of the year through Xbox Cloud Gaming.

Backbone Pro Smartphone Controller: Xbox Edition

$180 | Now available

This is the second Backbone controller to feature an Xbox theme, and this version of the Backbone Pro adopts the same aesthetics from the smaller Backbone device. It features a transparent design with a signature Xbox green colorway, and it uses a USB-C connection for Android smartphones and iPhones 15/17/17.

The Backbone Pro is designed to be the company's premium line of smartphone controllers, as it comes equipped with redesigned ergonomics and high-quality components like a textured finish, quieter face buttons, full-sized ALPS analog sticks, Hall Effect triggers, and two remappable back buttons.

"The Backbone One was and still is a great mobile controller--it's at the top of our phone controller best list (for now)--but the Backbone Pro offers a marked improvement in ergonomics, customization, and integration with the excellent dashboard and game launcher app," Steve Petite wrote in his breakdown of the Backbone Pro.

Backbone has revealed and released several new variations of its controllers throughout the year. Last month saw the announcement of the limited-edition Backbone One: Death Stranding 2 model and anyone looking for a cozy take on the hardware can pick up Backbone controllers that feature delicate pink and purple colorways. If you're looking to grab the cheaper and smaller Backbone One--and don't mind going without a few of the high-end features from the Backbone Pro, you can pick these up in neutral shades of black and white for $100.

Backbone One

  • Gen 2 (USB-C)
    • Black -- $100
    • White -- $100
  • Gen 2 (Lightning)
    • Black -- $100
    • White -- $100

Backbone Pro

  • Black -- $170
  • Grab A Wireless GameCube-Style Controller For Switch 1/2 & PC For Only $40
  • Amazon-Exclusive Lunar Remastered Collection Gets First Price Cut
  • Final Fantasy Magic: The Gathering Booster Box Restocked With Huge Discount At Amazon
  • + Show More More Gaming, Tech, and Entertainment Deals & Preorders Links (4)
  • Sunrise On The Reaping New Collector's Gift Edition Is Already Discounted At Amazon
  • Lego DC Batman Figure & Bat-Pod Is Over 50% Off At Amazon, Sold Out Everywhere Else
  • Honkai: Star Rail 8BitDo Ultimate 2 Collector's Bundle Gets First Discount
  • Xbox Elite Series 2 Deal: Save $60 On Microsoft's Premium Wireless Controller

item.title: Spider-Man: Miles Morales Enriched An Already Thriving New York
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Spider-Man: Miles Morales is celebrating its 5-year anniversary today, November 12, 2025. Below, we examine how the half-sequel capitalized on its smaller scope by telling a more intimate story.

Miles Morales swings past a small bodega as snow flurries catch the streetlights. Below him, vendors huddle in heavy coats, music spills from a corner bodega, and the streets of Harlem glow warm against the winter cold. The rhythm of the city seems to match his own momentum--fast, hopeful, alive. It’s familiar territory, but not quite the same New York Peter Parker protected previously. The city feels different now, more personal. It’s Miles’ home.

When Spider-Man: Miles Morales launched alongside the PlayStation 5 in November 2020, it didn’t look like a revolution. It wasn’t a full sequel, didn’t stretch across new boroughs, and didn’t introduce an entirely new rogues’ gallery. On paper, it was a stopgap--a smaller-scale spin-off meant to show off Sony’s new console and tide fans over until the next big thing.

But that undersells what Insomniac actually made. Instead of expanding outward, the studio looked inward. It took the same foundation that made Marvel’s Spider-Man such a triumph and reimagined it through a different lens. The result was a tighter, more emotional, and more focused adventure that did what few open-world games ever attempt: it made a familiar world feel new again.

The New York City Insomniac created in 2018 was already alive. The challenge wasn’t to make something bigger--it was to make something more meaningful.

Miles Morales is set during the winter holidays, with snow blanketing the rooftops and light reflecting off every icy windowpane. It’s the same city, but seen through different eyes. The change in season mirrors Miles himself: young, still growing, but confident enough to leave his own mark on a place that was once someone else’s domain.

In Harlem, where much of the story unfolds, the cultural heartbeat is unmistakable. Street murals honor local heroes, Puerto Rican flags flutter from apartment balconies, and conversations shift easily between English and Spanish. Miles himself, who has a Puerto Rican and African-American background, switches between the two throughout the story.

This New York is a living, breathing reflection of its new Spider-Man. It’s not Peter’s city anymore. It’s Miles’ world, infused with his rhythm and his energy.

“This is a full arc for Miles Morales that started in Spider-Man,” Insomniac creative director Brian Horton told Entertainment Weekly before the game's release. “We really are completing this hero’s coming of age in our game. It is a complete story.”

Spider-Man: Miles Morales narrows its focus in ways that make it stronger. Where Peter’s story in the first game revolved around juggling adulthood, heroism, and a sprawling cast of villains, Miles’ journey is quieter, more concentrated, and more personal.

“When we started crafting it,” Horton said. “We realized that, with a little bit more of a compact storytelling style, we could tell a very emotionally impactful story that would fit really well as an experience that would take Spider-Man 1 and [Miles Morales] and do justice to this character.”

That focus pays off. The story’s stakes aren’t world-ending- they’re local. When Harlem becomes the center of conflict between Roxxon Energy and the Underground, led by the Tinkerer, it feels personal. It was about about protecting home.

Too often, open-world games treat their worlds as disposable. Once the story ends, the setting is abandoned, its life frozen in time as NPCs wander the streets. Miles Morales takes a different approach.

By revisiting the same city and recontextualizing it through Miles’ perspective, Insomniac proved that open worlds don’t need to be replaced to stay relevant--they can evolve. Snowfall and holiday decorations give Manhattan a new visual identity, but it’s the emotional context that truly changes how players experience it. Familiar streets now hold new meaning because the character inhabiting them sees them differently.

That approach shows the value of continuity. Reusing assets wasn’t a shortcut; it was an opportunity to refine and enrich what already worked. Harlem’s sense of community, the mixtapes from Miles’ uncle, and the voices of neighbors echoing from windows all make the city feel lived in.

It’s a design philosophy other developers could learn from. Instead of chasing sheer size, studios could let their worlds age and transform alongside their characters. Imagine a series where time actually passes, where familiar places bear the marks of past adventures. Miles Morales hints at that kind of storytelling--one where the world grows with the hero. It's easier said than done, of course. Spider-man is a household franchise, but it's still something that could be experimented with.

Spider-Man and Miles Morales Full Story Recap

Want us to remember this setting for all your devices?

Sign up or Sign in now!

Please use a html5 video capable browser to watch videos.

This video has an invalid file format.

Sorry, but you can't access this content!

On the surface, Spider-Man: Miles Morales served as a technical showcase for the PS5. Its reflections glimmered with ray tracing, fast travel was instantaneous, and every frame highlighted the hardware’s power. But its real strength came from something far subtler: restraint.

At roughly ten hours, the main story moves with purpose. There’s less filler compared to almost every other open world adventure. The pacing mirrors Miles’ growth--bursts of electricity balanced by quiet confidence. By the time the story ends, players have watched him grow from an uncertain apprentice to a hero worthy of New York’s trust.

That focus gives the game a rhythm rarely found in open-world design. It doesn’t ask players to clear endless icons or grind through side missions that feel detached from the narrative.

Insomniac would later expand the formula again with Spider-Man 2, a bigger, flashier sequel that merged Peter and Miles’ stories into one city-spanning epic. But the lessons of Miles Morales linger.

The spin-off proved that smaller doesn’t mean lesser. It showed that revisiting a familiar world through new eyes can be as exciting as exploring somewhere brand new. And it reminded players that open worlds don’t need to expand endlessly--sometimes, they just need to evolve.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Black Ops 7 Day-One DLC Announced, Supports Military Veterans
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Activision has announced the first DLC for Call of Duty: Black Ops 7, and it'll be available at launch, with proceeds going to military veterans via the company's Call of Duty Endowment charity.

The C.O.D.E. Legacy: Tracer Pack is modeled on the real-world veteran Danielle Green, who lost her arm in combat and later worked with the robotics company Open Bionics on a new prosthetic arm. Green, who is a Purple Heart recipient, lost her arm while deployed in Iraq in 2004 when an RPG blast ripped off part of her left arm. The military police officer was conducting a rooftop security mission in Baghdad when her life changed forever.

"As I was about to return fire, something hit me," Green said. "Later [I learned] it was the blast, the RPG. When I was in the hospital, I decided to look down. That's when I realized that my left arm, my dominant arm, was shorter."

Green worked with Activision to create the DLC for Black Ops 7. She said, "This Veterans Day is special to me because I get to give back to my community and give veterans an opportunity to find meaningful jobs by being a part of the Call of Duty Endowment."

The DLC will launch alongside Black Ops 7 on November 14. Pricing was not announced, but it will likely be $20 like previous C.O.D.E. charity bundles were. All of the net proceeds will go to the charity, while military servicepeople and veterans can get the DLC for free.

The DLC pack include the Ironwill operator skin--it's based on Green and features her prosthetic arm. The bundle also include multiple weapon blueprints and other items.

Black Ops 7 is available to preload now. For more, check out the Black Ops 7 release times, including details on how to trick your console into thinking it's in New Zealand so you can play early.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Some Black Ops 7 Multiplayer Playlists Will Have SBMM, But Most Won't
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Ahead of Call of Duty: Black Ops 7's release on November 14, Activision has confirmed a key detail about the multiplayer mode. Some playlists will indeed have skill-based matchmaking toggled on, but most won't.

Developer Treyarch said on social media that the majority of the Black Ops 7 multiplayer playlists will have what is described as "open" matchmaking. In these playlists, skill is only "minimally considered," just as it was during the Black Ops 7 beta where Activision first rolled this out.

The exception for Black Ops 7 will be one rotating Moshpit playlist where "skill will be an important consideration." Additionally, Black Ops 7 Ranked play will feature SBMM when it launches in Season 2.

Treyarch also clarified that Black Ops 7 will feature persistent lobbies, which is what fans had asked for.

Hey everyone, to clarify: just like in the Black Ops 7 Beta, skill will be minimally considered in every Open playlist. We've also added persistent lobbies and new playlists since the Beta, including Quick Play.

Here's what you'll see on day one: pic.twitter.com/cEddWYzpAn

— Treyarch (@Treyarch) November 12, 2025

In October, Activision announced that Black Ops 7 multiplayer would be non-SBMM by default. Given that, some saw this recent announcement as Activision backpedaling on its original promise. But Activision never said Black Ops 7 would not have any SBMM playlists, only that non-SBMM will be the default for Black Ops 7 at launch.

For years, Call of Duty fans had asked Activision to deprioritize SBMM, and it's conspicuous that it's finally coming in a year when Battlefield 6 has a lot of momentum. Activision has not explained specifically why it's adding non-SBMM playlists to Black Ops 7.

In addition to standard multiplayer, Black Ops 7 will launch with a 20v20 mode called Skirmish in which players can fly with wingsuits and drive vehicles to traverse larger maps. There is a campaign mode, too, featuring an open-world Endgame element on the Avalon map, along with the return of Zombies.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/some-black-ops-7-multiplayer-playlists-will-have-sbmm-but-most-wont/1100-6536138/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
